div.head: Typology (Local)
div.p: East (Mashreq) > Egypt-Sudan > Egypt > Nile Valley > Upper Egypt
Sedentary dialects, some with Bedouin elements

div.head: General
div.p: The so-called Ṣaˁīdī dialects are defined by Woidich as those of the peasants in the Nile valley between Abū Tīg to Aswān, distinguishing them from “Middle Egyptian” spoken between al-Gīza and Abū Tīg and the oases dialects. There are supra-regional varieties used in songs and poetry.

div.head: Research history
div.p: Four dialect groups have been identified, stretching respectively from Sohāg to Luxor, Naǧˁ Ḥammādi to Gina, West Bank Luxor to Isna and Isna to Aswān.

Vycichl 1953 describes the language and customs of the ˁAbbādi. Khalafallah 1969 is a description of the Ṣaˁīdī grammar dealing with phonology and morphology, including stress and pitch, as well as syntax. It only provides one very short text. Doss 1981 is a PhD thesis on Ṣaˁīdī.

Woidich 1974 is an article on the Bˁēri-dialect on the west bank of Luxor. Nishio 1994 has described the dialect of Qifṭ. Behnstedt and Woidich’s Die ägyptisch-arabischen Dialekte covers the Ṣaˁīd, volume III, part 2 provides texts. Woidich has also authored the 1995 EI article on the Ṣaˁīd dialects. For a discussion of dialect mixing in Upper Egypt, see Woidich 1997.
Miller 2005 deals with linguistic accommodation of Ṣaˁīdi speakers in Cairo.
There are audio recordings from Abu Ṭišt, Biʿrāt, Dalawiyya, Ḥilla, Kitkāte, and ʿIzbit Basīli available at . SemArch.
